comment.author: 21734563@N04
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Veterans of the American Civil War, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 15319761@N06
comment._content: USS Agawam? Here's a link to the Naval Historical Center's entry on the Agawam, but the other pictures look like a different ship than this: http://www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-a/agawam.htm The officers look different too. It's a great image either way. A lot of interesting details, like telescope/field glass, something that looks like a bullhorn (held by the man on the top left), and the fact that the boy at top center is barefoot. Though my favorite element of being able to see these images in "high-def" is just to be able to see the faces.

comment.author: 15319761@N06
comment._content: Oops. I missed a note at the bottom of the Naval Historical Center's entry on the Agawam. It mentions this photograph, and says that it is actually an image of the USS Hunchback: Photo #: NH 51955 USS Hunchback (1862-1869) Some of the ship's officers and crewmen pose on deck, while she was serving on the James River, Virginia, in 1864-65. Photographed by Matthew Brady. Note swords, folding chairs and details of officer and enlisted uniforms. The original photograph has Brady negative number B-470. Note: This photograph has also been identified as having been taken on board USS Agawam, which it clearly was not. www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-h/hunchbk.htm
